thread.title: David Price not complaining about being skipped over for Game 1 of ALCS [Video]
thread.title_full: David Price not complaining about being skipped over for Game 1 of ALCS [Video]

title: David Price not complaining about being skipped over for Game 1 of ALCS [Video]
text:
MLB Playoffs KANSAS CITY - 
If Blue Jays would-be ace starter David Price has any issue with how he's been used so far these playoffs, you won't hear him complain about it. 
Saturday afternoon at Kauffman Stadium, he's hoping his left arm will do the talking, however. 
Passed over for the Game 1 start in the American League Championship Series, in part because of his relief appearance in Game 4 of the ALDS skirmish with the Texas Rangers, Price will get his next big opportunity in Game 2 of this round. 
Price, who took the loss in Game 1 against Texas, says he understands why he has been shuffled to Game 2 against the Royals. After throwing 50 pitches in relief of Dickey, he claims to be fine with it. 
“It doesn't matter,” Price said on Friday. “I mean, whatever the team wants me to do to try to help them win, I'm all about it. I knew I was going to be starting one of these games. 
“I completely get it and I'll be ready to go (on Saturday.)" 
Price had a 2.93 earned run average in two starts against the Royals this year and may match up better against them than he did against the Rangers. That's what the Jays are hoping for anyway. 
As brilliant as Price has been during the regular season -- and as big a part he played in the team getting to the post season -- he has struggled in the playoffs. He'll bring a 2-6 post-season, win-loss record into Saturday's contest. 
“No, I know it's going to come,” Price said when asked Friday whether he is feeling nervous about his past playoff efforts. “I have 100% confidence in myself. I know my teammates do as well -- and our coaching staff. 
“This is a part of it. You've got to be able to live in the moment. I want to be able to step up for my teammates and this organization and all our fans in Canada.” Sponsored Links
